item.title: reprex-ing with {datapasta} ğŸ
item.description: Scenario 1: from spreadsheet to reprex So, youâ€™ve been asked to make a reprex and you want to include a bit of data that you have in a spreadsheet.1 Meet {datapasta}, a package by Miles McBain that can make your life a whole lot easier. Once youâ€™ve installed datapasta, you simply copy a selected number of rows from your spreadsheet (remember, this is a minimal reproducible example), and select the Paste as tribble option from the DATAPASTA section of the Addins dropdown.

item.title: reprex-cellence ğŸ‘‘
item.description: In honour of the triumphant return of reprex to CRAN, letâ€™s revisit what I refer to as Jenny Bryanâ€™s keys to reprex-cellence.1 The three keys are as follows: code that actually runs code that I donâ€™t have to run code that can be easily run2 Our example True to the Ã©sprit de reprex, letâ€™s look at a real world example to unpack why these attributes are so useful.

Hadley (in which youâ€™ll learn how to make a very awesome Vincent-Vega version of an mtcars scatter-plot, below).

item.title: Docker-izing your work in R ğŸ³
item.description: Updated: 2018-08-19 I am decidedly a novice when it comes to any and all things Docker (which, incidentally, is why Iâ€™ve been reading these posts). But, since itâ€™s helpful for me to have all of these resources together in one place, I thought Iâ€™d share the love around.1 R Docker turorial for reproducible research. via rOpenSci Labs This is actually a series of 6 lessons put together at the rOpenSci unconf in 2016.

item.title: R-blog ğŸ“ tips from an inveterate tweeter thereof
item.description: Preemptive peccavi This post is selfish. The following items are tips, only insofar as they are to my liking. Whatâ€™s more, the material isnâ€™t even original. I wrote these up in response to a thread on the RStudio Community site.1 So, consider yourselves warned. â˜ ï¸ 1. Put a bird on it. ğŸ¦ Actually, not just a bird (damn my dedication to TV show references), Iâ€™d recommend having your twitter handle (if youâ€™re on there) visible in writing.

item.title: Goodreads ğŸ‘ğŸ“š Part 2: rvesting descriptions
item.description: Preamble Much of the code herein has been adapted from the excellent post â€œWhere my girls at? Scraping Goodreads and using ML to estimate how many childrenâ€™s books have a cetnral female characterâ€ by Giora Simchoni, which I highly recommend. Iâ€™ll also make reference to my earlier post using my Goodreads data, should you want to check that out. ğŸ˜± Why arenâ€™t you using the API?! Calm down! Yes, I know there is a perfectly lovely Goodreads APIâ€“ and, by â€œperfectly lovelyâ€ I mean for getting pretty much any data other than book descriptions (which, as you will soon discover, are the objects of my desire).

item.title: ğŸ™ˆ mousey methods
item.description: Why show us the wrong way? I know, this seems like a perverse manner of going about things, but these are ways of getting information that will help others to help you. This means that thereâ€™s a decent chance youâ€™re new to this whole endeavor, and may need some stop-gap, familiar methods before you begin to feel comfortable with best practices. There are good reasons to steer clear of your ğŸ’½ mouse.

item.title: Keeping up with blogdown ğŸŒŸ
item.description: Updated: 2018-08-30 Iâ€™ve loved blogdown ğŸ“¦ for so long, that I was kind of shocked ğŸ˜± when I saw Yinui Xieâ€™s post, Announcing blogdown: Create Websites with R Markdown, on the RStudio blog just last month! Have people really been living without the magic âœ¨ of blogdown in their lives for so long?! If you are one of these people, then hopefully this post (which, yes, is really just a roundup of tweets) will inspire you to join in on the fun ğŸ‘¯.

item.title: Custom snippets in RStudio: âš¡ faster tweet chunks for all
item.description: âœ‚ï¸ Snippets in RStudio As Sean Lopp describes in his super helpful post, RStudio IDE Easy Tricks You Mightâ€™ve Missed â­: Code snippets are a shortcut to insert common boilerplate code. You might also refer to them as â€œtext macrosâ€1â€” either way, theyâ€™re useful for speeding up the process of doing a thing in RStudio that you do frequently. In my case, this includes inserting â€œtweet chunksâ€ in blogdown posts using a Hugo shortcode.

item.title: ğŸ˜¸ purrr-ty posts

This cheatsheet will remind you how to manipulate lists with purrr as well as how to apply functions iteratively to each element of a list or vector.

item.title: RegEx resources
item.description: Updated: ğŸ“† 2018-04-06. Regular Expressions, RegEx, regexpsâ€“ call them what you like, but no matter how you slice it, theyâ€™re useful af. After all, data spelunking is all about patterns, and thatâ€™s precisely what regexps are for: (wo)manhandling patterns in strings. Good Sirs Wickham and Grolemund, in their masterful tome, r4ds, describe them thusly: They [regexps] take a little while to get your head around, but once you understand them, youâ€™ll find them extremely useful.

item.title: R workflow fun
item.description: I was excited to see Declutter your R workflow with tidy tools1, a preprint by Zev Ross, Hadley Wickham, and David Robinson, among the many excellent papers in the Practical Data Science for Stats PeerJ collection.2 Workflows, whether data-analysis-related or not, are never a one-size-fits-all matter of course. Among other things, the workflows here differ in scope (heck, one of them doesnâ€™t even use R). That said, thereâ€™s lots to be learned from the processes, mistakes, and hard-wrought wisdom ğŸ¦‰ of others.

item.title: tidyeval resource roundup
item.description: Updated: 2018-10-06 Though, naturally, the Honorable Professor Doctor Sir Lord General Hadley Wickhamâ€™s Programming with dplyr article is the ne plus ultra of getting oneself aquainted with the latest and greatest in tidyeval programming recipes, quoting, and quasiquotation; there are some other resources out there. After posting a link to Edwin Thoenâ€™s â­ï¸ Tidy evaluation, most common actions, I was asked if there were other tidyeval tutorials I knew of.

item.title: Onboarding with rOpenSci: Tandem tales of package review
item.description: On of the ways in which rOpenSci does such a stellar job of package â€œquality controlâ€ is through its open, peer-review onboarding process. I had the chance to take part in this by reviewing Nicholas Tierneyâ€™s awesome visdat package ğŸ“¦. In what Iâ€™m told is an rOpenSci first, Nick and I both wrote up our experiences for the rOpenSci blog â€” giving you a peek into the reviewer and reviewee process.

item.title: Stringr Visual Cheat Sheet
item.description: So, kinda the whole point of this â€œmaking-a-blogâ€ endeavor (aside from getting to play with Yihui Xieâ€™s super awesome blogdown ğŸ“¦) was to give a more permanent home to some of the resources Iâ€™ve found and/or tweeted. So, without further adoâ€¦ stringr Â«aide-mÃ©moireÂ» This visual guide (or cheat sheet, if you prefer) was made by Lise Vaudor (@LVaudor on twitter), and originally shared in her blog post, Manipuler des strings avec R.

item.title: ğŸ‘ğŸ“š Part 1: rgoodreads ğŸ“¦
item.description: ğŸ¤“ What is â€œnormalâ€ reading? There are very few things considered â€œnormalâ€ (in the â€œordinaryâ€ sense of the word) about my reading habits. Letâ€™s just say that, when I saw #BookLoversDay was trending on Twitter, my first thought was: it me! However, it also served as a reminder of my struggles regarding reading and â€œnormalcyâ€ of the Gaussian distribution variety.1 My beef is not with books themselves, but rather the limitations of rating them on Goodreads using a restrictive 5-star scale.

item.title: Boston EARL Keynote
